text: did you know you don't have to belong to
a party to get elected to Parliament I
thought okay so why do we have political
parties well it all started with the
Whigs and the Tories more than 300 years
ago they were groupings in Parliament
that clashed over things like monarchy
and religion but it's still took a while
until political parties as we know them
today took shape in the UK now there are
more than 350 of them though less than
10 were represented in the last
Parliament so what purpose do parties
actually serve put very simply political
parties are made up of people who share
similar views on how the country should
be run that's why we hear a lot about
what parties want to do if they get into
power during an election campaign this
should make it easier for voters to know
what candidates from different parties
stand for and how they would act in
Parliament but there's no rule that says
MPs have to follow their party line or
even stay in the party once they're
elected in fact more than 30 MPs ended
this Parliament outside the party they
belong to when they were voted in two
years ago still being a member of a
party has its perks running in an
election that's like a tongue twister
running in an election can be expensive
and parties can support their candidates
with money campaign help and media
coverage now of course political parties
are not just made up of people running
for Parliament the biggest party in the
UK labour has close to half a million
members and our party membership used to
be a lot higher although there has been
a recent upturn but on Election Day its
votes not membership that count and it
seems that voters today are less loyal
than they used to be in fact almost half
switch parties at least once over the
last three elections this may be partly
because people are choosing to vote on
single issues that are important to them
and they look for the party or candidate
the best represents their views on that
issue
take brexit an issue that divides
parties as much as it does voters
Pro and anti brexit candidates are
scattered across the main parties and
voters might choose to support a
candidate regardless of whether they
agree with their party's declared
position so is this the beginning of the
end for political parties that's
unlikely party still undeniably matter a
great deal in politics after all it's
usually the biggest party in parliament
that gets to form a government and
decide how the country is actually run
